Lang Ice Company has developed an Emergency Response Plan (ERP) that contains procedures designed to maximize the safety of all employees, contractors, and visitors in the event of an emergency and also guard against environmental consequences.

III. Facility Identification
The Lang Ice Company facility is located at 3600 West 59th Street in Chicago, Illinois.  The facility is a producer, distributor, and retailer of ice for the Chicagoland area.  

The NAICS code for the facility is 312113. Ammonia refrigeration is used at the facility to make and store ice.   

The facility uses ammonia for refrigeration, and is regulated under 40 CFR Part 68, the EPA RMP Rule.  The amount of ammonia currently present in the refrigeration system is approximately 20,000 pounds.

A topographic map identifying the site location is included as Appendix A. An area map is included as Appendix B.

VI. General Accidental Release Prevention Program
A prevention program is in place to minimize the risk of hazardous chemical releases in accordance with the OSHA Process Safety Management (PSM) standard (29 CFR 1910.119) and the EPA Risk Management Program.   However, as discussed throughout this document Lang Ice is continuously working on improving this program. 

This prevention program covers those processes that handle ammonia above the threshol

d quantity for both PSM and RMP rules. The next audit of the PSM program will occur by July 17, 2011, in compliance with the requirement to conduct PSM audits every three years.  The elements of the PSM / Program 3 prevention program and a brief description are listed below.
? Employee Participation ? Lang Ice Company has updated a site-specific employee participation plan that ensures employees and their representatives are consulted when conducting and developing process hazard analyses and other information required to be developed under the PSM/RMP regulation.  In addition, the employee participation program will ensure employees and their representatives have access to process hazard analyses and all other information required to be developed under PSM/RMP.  
? Process Safety Information ? Lang Ice Company maintains a site-specific PSI program that ensures information pertaining to the hazards, technology, and equipment of the process are properly developed and maintained. Process safety information for the ammonia process has been compiled and was last reviewed and updated as of February 11, 2009.
? Process Hazard Review ? Lang Ice Company has updated a site-specific PHA program that ensures a PHA is conducted initially, at a minimum of every five (5) years, and whenever a change is significant enough to require a change in PSI.  In addition, this program ensures PHAs are conducted in accordance with OSHA and EPA regulations and ensures findings and recommendations of PHAs are properly documented. Lang Ice Company conducted a thorough PHA study for ammonia system on February 11-13, 2009.
? Operating Procedures ? Lang Ice Company has updated a site-specific procedure that ensures operating procedures provide clear instruction for different phases of process operations and ensures they are properly maintained.  Lang Ice Company most recently reviewed the procedures during November, 2008.  Annually, the operating procedures will be reviewed and certified as accur

ate.
? Training ? Lang Ice Company has updated a site-specific training procedure that ensures employees operating the ammonia process have the knowledge to safely operate the process, are aware of the potential hazards of the process, and understand the causes of process problems.
? Management of Change ? Lang Ice Company has updated a site-specific management of change procedure that ensures changes (except for replacement in kind) to the ammonia process, such as additions of new equipment or changes in operating, maintenance, or other procedures are documented. The most recent management of change occurred on October 1, 2008.
? Pre-Startup Review ? Lang Ice Company has updated a site-specific pre-startup safety review procedure that ensures a safety review is performed when modifications to the ammonia process are significant enough to require a change in PSI.  The most recent PSSR was conducted on February 2, 2009.
? Mechanical Integrity ? Lang Ice Company has updated a site-specific mechanical integrity procedure that ensures written preventative maintenance procedures are developed and maintained, preventative maintenance tests and inspections are properly documented, and employees maintaining the process receive adequate training.  Lang Ice Company most recently conducted equipment inspections during May 2009.
? Contractor Qualifications ? Lang Ice Company has updated a site-specific contractor qualification procedure that ensures all contract employers? safety performance and programs are evaluated, a contract employee injury and illness log is maintained, information of potential hazards are communicated between Lang Ice Company and the contract employer, and required training and information is communicated, such as the provisions of the emergency response plan and control over entrance into process areas.
? Incident Investigation ? Lang Ice Company has updated a site-specific incident investigation procedure that ensures each incident that either results

in a release or could have resulted in a release of anhydrous ammonia is investigated, within 48 hours, by a team of at least one person knowledgeable in the process.  This procedure will also make provisions to ensure a report is prepared at the conclusion of the investigation and findings are promptly addressed. 
? Compliance Audit ? Lang Ice Company has updated a site-specific compliance audit program that ensures compliance audits are conducted at a minimum of every three years to verify that Lang Ice Company PSM/RMP practices and procedures are adequate and are being followed.  A compliance audit was conducted on July 17, 2008, and the next compliance audit will be conducted by July 17, 2011.  
? Hot Work Permits ? Lang Ice Company has updated a best management practice for hot work.  Lang Ice Company most recently reviewed the hot work procedure during January 2009.

VII. Five-Year Accident History
The Lang Ice facility encountered one (1) accidental release, which resulted in a reportable quantity anhydrous ammonia, in the last five years.

VIII. Emergency Response Program
Lang Ice Company has developed an Emergency Response Plan (ERP) to ensure that in the event of an emergency the facility personnel are aware of the appropriate actions to take and authorities to contact in order to mitigate the effects of a release. 

Lang Ice Company has communicated and trained facility employees on proper evacuation procedures and has had interaction (i.e. onsite inspections) with the Chicago Fire Department. 

Lang Ice Company has coordinated their ERP with the City of Chicago Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC) and the Chicago Fire Department.  This coordination effort includes providing each aforementioned agency with a copy of our ERP, providing each with a site diagram and hazardous material information, meeting with Chicago Fire Department personnel to discuss the facilities operations/processes, and encouraging periodic on-site inspections and coordination w

ith Chicago Fire Department personnel.

Lang Ice Company?s hazardous materials response team will be responsible for investigating and assisting the Chicago Fire Department (if necessary) with response to accidental releases of ammonia. 

Several employees on staff have received HAZWOPER training through classroom instruction, on-the-job training and drills. The current HAZWOPER training includes the first responder awareness level, the first responder operations level and hazardous materials technician training.   

The facility has two (2) windsocks (one at the shipping dock and one in the employee parking lot) present onsite for use in determining wind direction in the event of an ammonia release and evacuation of the building.

The current Material Safety Data Sheet (MSDS) for anhydrous ammonia is included in Appendix F. 

IX. Emergency Communications
The telephone numbers of agencies and plant personnel that may be contacted in case of an emergency are available onsite.

X. Planned Changes to Improve Safety
Chemical safety is an important part of Lang Ice Company operations. Lang Ice Company recently conducted an audit of their Process Safety Management Program and will be dutifully implementing the recommendations from that audit. Continuous improvement in safety is an important goal for Lang Ice Company. 

XI. Management Program
Lang Ice Company has updated a management system to oversee the implementation of the risk management program elements.  This system has assigned qualified person(s) (or position) to assist in the development, implementation, and integration of the risk management program elements.  If any portion of the program is delegated to others, the names or positions of those individuals will be documented and the lines of authority defined through an organization chart or similar document.  Currently, Dane Irelan, Environmental Health and Safety Manager, is responsible for implementation of the overall Risk Management Program.
